newsitem.title: USA: Kmart, Gap report higher first-quarter earnings.
newsitem.headline: Kmart, Gap report higher first-quarter earnings.

text.p: Kmart Corp. Thursday reported a profit for the first quarter, compared with a loss a year earlier, as costs declined while sales grew.
"Kmart's earnings for the first quarter were on plan, with good balance between sales, gross margin and expense controls," said Floyd Hall, chairman, president and chief executive officer.
The nation's No. 2 retailer had a first-quarter profit of $14 million, or three cents a share, up from a loss of $99 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier.
The year-ago period included charges of $63 million, or 13 cents per share, related to the disposal of Kmart's stakes in Thrifty PayLess Holdings, Inc. and Builders Square.
Sales rose to $7.26 billion from $6.97 billion a year earlier.
The discount store giant said selling, general and administrative expenses fell to $1.49 billion from $1.52 billion in the first quarter of 1996.
"We saw solid performance in our Big Kmart high frequency conversions, and were very pleased with the introduction of the new Martha Stewart Everyday bed and bath lines," Hall said.
"Product-line extensions for Martha Stewart and the new offering of our Sesame Street line of children's apparel this summer are also expected to enhance our customer appeal, " he said.
Kmart has 2,122 U.S. retail outlets and operates 123 stores internationally.
Its stock was unchanged at $14.50 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
San Francisco-based Gap Inc. reported higher earnings on an 11 percent increase in sales.
Gap, which operates 1,916 Gap, Banana Republic, GapKids and Old Navy stores, said earnings rose to $84.3 million, or 31 cents a share, from $81.6 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier.
Sales rose to $1.23 billion from $1.11 billion.

"I'm pleased we can report improved earnings in what has been a difficult environment. We are continuing to make progress toward our main objectives: building our brands and growing our businesses," said Millard S. Drexler, president and chief executive officer.

"We have taken steps to strengthen our Gap brand, where we've had some short-term challenges," he said. "We named Robert Fisher to lead the division, and we returned to national television advertising with an exciting campaign aimed at our Gap brand target audience."
Gap's stock gained $1.50 to $33.625 on the NYSE.
